Hello, subscriber!

Welcome to the second lesson in our coffee journey. Hopefully, you're sipping something delicious as you read.

How coffee is processed after harvest?

Coffee beans: Lesson 2

After coffee cherries are harvested from the trees, they don’t become the familiar roasted beans we know and love overnight. There's an intricate post-harvest process that plays a big role in the final flavor of the coffee in your cup.

There are several methods used to process coffee, but the three most common are: washed (or wet) process, natural (or dry) process, and honey (or semi-washed) process.

Washed Process (Wet Process)

In the washed method, the fruit covering the beans is removed before they are dried. After picking, the cherries are pulped (removing the skin and most of the fruit), and then the beans are fermented in water for 12–72 hours to break down any remaining mucilage (that sticky fruit layer). They are then washed with clean water and laid out to dry on patios or raised beds.

This method tends to produce a cleaner, brighter flavor with more pronounced acidity. Coffees from Central America and East Africa are often processed this way.

Natural Process (Dry Process)

This is the oldest method and still common in regions with less access to water. The whole cherries are dried in the sun, with the beans still inside the fruit. After drying for weeks, the fruit is mechanically removed.

Naturally processed coffees often have a fruitier, sweeter, and fuller-bodied profile, but can be inconsistent if not carefully monitored. It’s common in countries like Ethiopia and Brazil.

Honey Process (Semi-Washed)

This method is a hybrid. The skin of the cherry is removed, but some or all of the sticky mucilage is left on during drying. Depending on how much mucilage is left, you may hear terms like black honey, red honey, or yellow honey, which refer to increasing amounts of mucilage and corresponding sweetness and body.

Honey-processed coffees balance the acidity of washed coffees with the sweetness and complexity of natural ones. It’s particularly popular in Costa Rica.

Each of these processing methods dramatically affects the flavor, aroma, and body of the coffee. As a result, even beans from the same farm can taste very different depending on how they’re processed.

Next time you're shopping for coffee or sipping a new brew, check if the label mentions the processing method — you might start finding a favorite style.
